channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Leaders at E.U. Summit Vow to ‘Regain Control’ of Borders
item.description: The bloc’s last scheduled meeting this year focused on the influx of migrants, with leaders promising only to act on past decisions, and on Britain’s future membership.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, left, with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany at the European Union summit meeting in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Britain Considers Deflating Power of House of Lords
item.description: A special panel investigating the upper chamber of the British Parliament has published recommendations on curbing its powers.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Monument Re-evaluated
item.description: The new Liberal government said that a monument to victims of Communism proposed by a private group would not be built next to the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: ISIS Carries Out First ‘Serious’ Attack in Northern Iraq in Months, U.S. Says
item.description: The Islamic State launched its largest attack in more than five months in a possible show of strength ahead of a visit by Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing: United Nations: Sanctions Against ISIS Adopted
item.description: The Security Council adopted a resolution aimed at preventing banned terrorist groups from making money and using the international banking system.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Israel and Turkey Agree to Restore Diplomatic Ties
item.description: Turkey will drop charges against Israeli officers in the deaths of Turkish activists aboard a ship in 2010, and Israel will establish a fund for the victims’ families.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: A Israeli military speed boat escorted the Turkish ship Mavi Marmara after Israeli forces raided it as it approached Gaza in May 2010. Ten people were killed in the confrontation, which led to recriminations between Turkey and Israel.

item.title: Desertions Slow Progress of Afghan Air Force Training in U.S.
item.description: Afghan officials hope to curb the problem before it further depletes the nascent air force and jeopardizes millions of dollars in American training efforts.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Afghan Air Force inspecting a helicopter in Kabul in September.

item.title: Under Fire From G.O.P., Obama Defends Response to Terror Attacks
item.description: President Obama acknowledged he was slow to respond to public fears, but said sending ground forces back to the Middle East could result in 100 American deaths every month.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: President Obama delivers remarks earlier this month.

item.title: Report Criticizes U.N.’s Handling of Child Sex Abuse Allegations
item.description: A panel said the United Nations failed to meet its own standards in investigating allegations of the abuse of boys by French soldiers in the Central African Republic.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: In Transit: U.S. Airlines Preparing to Offer Flights to Cuba
item.description: With the United States and Cuba agreeing to restore commercial flights between the countries, U.S. carriers have begun planning service.
item.dc:creator: SHIVANI VORA
item.media:description: JetBlue plans to apply for new routes to Cuba after it has reviewed the terms of the agreement and is clearer on the process.

item.title: Libya’s Rival Factions Sign Deal for Unity Government
item.description: Western powers hope that the United Nations-brokered agreement will bring stability and help fight a growing Islamic State presence in the North African country.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY

item.title: I.M.F. Chief Faces Trial in Case Dating to Time as French Finance Minister
item.description: An order by the French Court of Justice could mean that Ms. Lagarde will be embroiled in a lengthy process to address accusations stemming from a 2007 arbitration case.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, in September.

item.title: U.N. Rights Council Presses for Inquiry in Burundi
item.description: At least 400 people have died since April, a human rights official said, stemming from protests after the president decided to run for a third term.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: At least 87 people were killed in Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi, last week when the police and security forces reacted to attacks on two military camps.

item.title: Jerusalem Attacks Subside, but Not Palestinian Ire, as Israel Clamps Down
item.description: Most attacks are now carried out by Palestinians from the West Bank, rather than East Jerusalem, but some predict that Israel’s tough policies will backfire.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and RAMI NAZZAL
item.media:description: The home of a Palestinian assailant was demolished in East Jerusalem by the Israeli authorities, part of a response to attacks.

item.title: Brazil Restores WhatsApp Service After Brief Blockade Over Wiretap Request
item.description: The two-day blockade was ordered by a judge in São Paulo after Facebook, which owns WhatsApp, defied orders for a wiretap requested in a criminal court proceeding.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL and VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: Iran Registers Clerics Seeking to Choose Next Supreme Leader
item.description: The clerics want to be among the 86 Islamic theologians on the Council of Experts, where hard-liners and moderate are competing for control.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Repaired King Tut Mask Back on Display in Egypt
item.description: The gilded funeral mask of King Tutankhamen has been returned to the Egyptian Museum after eight weeks of delicate surgery to undo damage caused by a botched repair last year.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: The restored funeral mask of King Tutankhamen was displayed at the Egyptian Museum on Wednesday.

item.title: Vladimir Putin Chides Turkey, Praises Trump and Talks Up Russia’s Economy
item.description: Mr. Putin forecast that the slumping economy would soon rebound and praised efforts by Secretary of State John Kerry to find a political solution in Syria.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Memo From Jakarta: Indonesian Speaker’s Downfall Sets Precedent in a Corruption-Addled Nation
item.description: The resignation of the House speaker, Setya Novanto, who was recorded apparently soliciting a bribe from a mining giant, could be Indonesia’s Watergate moment.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Speaker Setya Novanto of the House of Representatives leaving a hearing with the Ethics Council in Jakarta earlier in December. He resigned his post on Wednesday hours before the council voted to remove him.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: How to Fix Latin America’s ‘Strongman’ Problem
item.description: Demand that presidents step down for at least one term before they can run for re-election. This may be easier for them to accept.
item.dc:creator: DAVID LANDAU, BRIAN SHEPPARD and ROSALIND DIXON
item.media:description: Demonstrators clash with riot police during a protest over presidential term limits in Ecuador.
